title: How one family built a brand new country house in a Georgian body
text:
Charles Pearson’s house near Petworth in West Sussex appears quite suddenly from the bottom gate, its Portland stone gleaming in the sun, a bowl full of sheep grazing below. Over the ­cattle grid, the drive winds around, not a stone out of place.

Pitshill has been a 20-year labour of love for Pearson, 63, the younger son of the 3rd Viscount Cowdray and scion of the construction-turned-publishing business. Part of his childhood was spent in Sussex, and he knew the house’s previous owners, the Barclay family.

He attended his first disco in the house, where a glitter ball hung in the room that is now his study. “There were girls there, which was terrifying, as I had never met any apart from my sisters,”...
